member.name: T:Deveel.Math.BigDecimal
member.summary: This class represents immutable arbitrary precision decimal numbers.
member.remarks: Each instance is represented with a unscaled arbitrary precision mantissa (the unscaled value) and a scale. The value of the is 10^(-).

member.summary: An array with the zero number scaled by the first positive scales. (0*10^0, 0*10^1, ..., 0*10^10).

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.BigDecimal._precision
member.summary: Represent the number of decimal digits in the unscaled value.
member.remarks: This precision is calculated the first time, and used in the following calls of method . Note that some call to the private method could update this field.

member.name: M:Deveel.Math.BigDecimal.#ctor(System.Double)
member.summary: Constructs a new instance from the 64bit double . The constructed big decimal is equivalent to the given double.
member.param: The double value to be converted to a instance.
member.remarks:
For example, new BigDecimal(0.1) is equal to 0.1000000000000000055511151231257827021181583404541015625. This happens as 0.1 cannot be represented exactly in binary.
To generate a big decimal instance which is equivalent to 0.1 use the method.
member.exception: If is infinity or not a number.

For example, new BigDecimal(0.1) is equal to 0.1000000000000000055511151231257827021181583404541015625. This happens as 0.1 cannot be represented exactly in binary.
To generate a big decimal instance which is equivalent to 0.1 use the constructor.
member.exception: If is infinity or not a number.
if of is greater than 0 and is equal to and the new big decimal cannot be represented within the given precision without rounding.

member.name: P:Deveel.Math.BigDecimal.Scale
member.summary: Gets the scale value of this instance
member.remarks: The scale is the number of digits behind the decimal point. The value of this is the unsignedValue * 10^(-scale). If the scale is negative, then this represents a big integer.

member.name: P:Deveel.Math.BigDecimal.Precision

remarks.para: The precision is the number of decimal digits used to represent this decimal. It is equivalent to the number of digits of the unscaled value.
The precision of 0 is 1 (independent of the scale).

members.member:
Returns {@code true} if {@code x} is a {@code BigDecimal} instance and if this instance is equal to this big decimal. Two big decimals are equal if their unscaled value and their scale is equal. For example, 1.0 (10*10^(-1)) is not equal to 1.00 (100*10^(-2)). Similarly, zero instances are not equal if their scale differs.
@param x object to be compared with {@code this}. @return true if {@code x} is a {@code BigDecimal} and {@code this == x}.

Returns this {@code BigDecimal} as an long value. Any fractional part is discarded. If the integral part of {@code this} is too big to be represented as an long, then {@code this} % 2^64 is returned.
@return this {@code BigDecimal} as a long value.

Returns this {@code BigDecimal} as an int value. Any fractional part is discarded. If the integral part of {@code this} is too big to be represented as an int, then {@code this} % 2^32 is returned.
@return this {@code BigDecimal} as a int value.

Returns this {@code BigDecimal} as a short value if it has no fractional part and if its value fits to the short range ([-2^{15}..2^{15}-1]). If these conditions are not met, an {@code ArithmeticException} is thrown.
@return this {@code BigDecimal} as a short value. @throws ArithmeticException if rounding is necessary of the number doesn't fit in a short.

member.name: M:Deveel.Math.BigDecimal.Plus(Deveel.Math.MathContext)
member.remarks: Returns a new whose value is +this.
member.param: Rounding mode and precision for the result of this operation.
member.remarks: The result is rounded according to the passed context .

members.member:
Returns a new {@code BigDecimal} instance with the same value as {@code this} but with a unscaled value where the trailing zeros have been removed. If the unscaled value of {@code this} has n trailing zeros, then the scale and the precision of the result has been reduced by n.
@return a new {@code BigDecimal} instance equivalent to this where the trailing zeros of the unscaled value have been removed.

member.name: T:Deveel.Math.BigInteger
member.summary: This class represents immutable integer numbers of arbitrary length.
member.remarks:
Large numbers are typically used in security applications and therefore BigIntegers offer dedicated functionality like the generation of large prime numbers or the computation of modular inverse.
Since the class was modeled to offer all the functionality as the {@link Integer} class does, it provides even methods that operate bitwise on a two's complement representation of large integers. Note however that the implementations favors an internal representation where magnitude and sign are treated separately. Hence such operations are inefficient and should be discouraged. In simple words: Do NOT implement any bit fields based on BigInteger.

members.member: The magnitude of this big integer. This array holds unsigned little endian digits. For example: {@code 13} is represented as [ 13 ] {@code -13} is represented as [ 13 ] {@code 2^32 + 13} is represented as [ 13, 1 ] {@code 2^64 + 13} is represented as [ 13, 0, 1 ] {@code 2^31} is represented as [ Integer.MIN_VALUE ] The magnitude array may be longer than strictly necessary, which results in additional trailing zeros.
The length of this in measured in ints. Can be less than digits.length().
The sign of this.

member.name: P:Deveel.Math.BigInteger.BitCount
member.summary: Gets the number of bits in the binary representation of this integer which differ from the sign bit.

remarks.para: If this integer is positive the result is equivalent to the number of bits set in the binary representation of this. If this integer is negative the result is equivalent to the number of bits set in the binary representation of -this-1.
Note: Usage of this property is not recommended as the current implementation is not efficient.

member.summary: A utility for constructing a big integer from a long
member.param: The source value of the conversion
member.returns: Returns an instance of that is created from the source value specified.

members.member:
Returns this {@code BigInteger} as an float value. If {@code this} is too big to be represented as an float, then {@code Float.POSITIVE_INFINITY} or {@code Float.NEGATIVE_INFINITY} is returned. Note, that not all integers x in the range [-Float.MAX_VALUE, Float.MAX_VALUE] can be represented as a float. The float representation has a mantissa of length 24. For example, 2^24+1 = 16777217 is returned as float 16777216.0.
@return this {@code BigInteger} as a float value.

Returns this {@code BigInteger} as an double value. If {@code this} is too big to be represented as an double, then {@code Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY} or {@code Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY} is returned. Note, that not all integers x in the range [-Double.MAX_VALUE, Double.MAX_VALUE] can be represented as a double. The double representation has a mantissa of length 53. For example, 2^53+1 = 9007199254740993 is returned as double 9007199254740992.0.
@return this {@code BigInteger} as a double value

member.returns: Returns a new that is the result of the addition of the two integers specified

member.name: M:Deveel.Math.BigMath.ShiftRight(Deveel.Math.BigInteger,System.Int32)
member.summary: Shifts the given big integer on the right by the given distance
member.param: The integer value to shif
The shift distance

remarks.para: For negative arguments, the result is also negative.The shift distance may be negative which means that is shifted left.
Note: Usage of this method on negative values is not recommended as the current implementation is not efficient.

The result is equivalent to value * 2^n if n is greater than or equal to 0. The shift distance may be negative which means that is shifted right.The result then corresponds to floor(value / 2 ^ (-n)).
Note: Usage of this method on negative values is not recommended as the current implementation is not efficient.

The second term of the oepration
member.remarks: Note: Usage of this method is not recommended as the current implementation is not efficient.
member.returns: Returns a new whose value is the result of an logical and between the given numbers.
member.exception: If either or is null.

members.member: @see BigInteger#shiftRight(int)
Performs {@code val >>= count} where {@code val} is a positive number.
Static library that provides {@link BigInteger} base conversion from/to any integer represented in an {@link java.lang.String} Object.
Holds the maximal exponent for each radix, so that radixdigitFitInInt[radix] fit in an {@code int} (32 bits).
bigRadices values are precomputed maximal powers of radices (integer numbers from 2 to 36) that fit into unsigned int (32 bits). bigRadices[0] = 2 ^ 31, bigRadices[8] = 10 ^ 9, etc.
@see BigInteger#ToString(int)
@see BigInteger#ToDouble()

Static library that provides all operations related with division and modular arithmetic to {@link BigInteger}. Some methods are provided in both mutable and immutable way. There are several variants provided listed below:
Division
{@link BigInteger} division and remainder by {@link BigInteger}.
{@link BigInteger} division and remainder by {@code int}.
gcd between {@link BigInteger} numbers.
Modular arithmetic
Modular exponentiation between {@link BigInteger} numbers.
Modular inverse of a {@link BigInteger} numbers.
Calculates a.modInverse(p) Based on: Savas, E; Koc, C "The Montgomery Modular Inverse - Revised"
Calculate the first digit of the inverse
@return bi == abs(2^exp)

Performs modular exponentiation using the Montgomery Reduction. It requires that all parameters be positive and the modulus be even. Based The square and multiply algorithm and the Montgomery Reduction C. K. Koc - Montgomery Reduction with Even Modulus. The square and multiply algorithm and the Montgomery Reduction.
@ar.org.fitc.ref "C. K. Koc - Montgomery Reduction with Even Modulus" @see BigInteger#modPow(BigInteger, BigInteger)

Static library that provides the basic arithmetic mutable operations for {@link BigInteger}. The operations provided are listed below.
Addition.
Subtraction.
Comparison.
In addition to this, some Inplace (mutable) methods are provided.
Just to denote that this class can't be instantiated
@see BigInteger#add(BigInteger)
Performs {@code res = a + b}.
@see BigInteger#subtract(BigInteger)
Performs {@code res = a - b}. It is assumed the magnitude of a is not less than the magnitude of b.

Adds an integer value to the array of integers remembering carry.
@return a possible generated carry (0 or 1)
Performs: {@code op1 += addend}. The number must to have place to hold a possible carry.

Performs {@code op1 -= op2}. {@code op1} must have enough place to store the result (i.e. {@code op1.bitLength() >= op2.bitLength()}). Both should be positive (what implies that {@code op1 >= op2}).
@param op1 the input minuend, and the output result. @param op2 the subtrahend
Performs {@code res = b - a}
Compares two arrays, representing unsigned integer in little-endian order. Returns +1,0,-1 if a is - respective - greater, equal or lesser then b

The library implements some logical operations over {@code BigInteger}. The operations provided are listed below.
not
and
andNot
or
xor
@see BigInteger#not()
@see BigInteger#and(BigInteger)
@see BigInteger#andNot(BigInteger)
@see BigInteger#or(BigInteger)
@return sign = 1, magnitude = longer.magnitude | shorter.magnitude
@return sign = -1, magnitude = -(-val.magnitude | -that.magnitude)
@return sign = -1, magnitude = -(positive.magnitude | -negative.magnitude)
@see BigInteger#xor(BigInteger)
@return sign = 0, magnitude = longer.magnitude | shorter.magnitude
@return sign = 0, magnitude = -val.magnitude ^ -that.magnitude
@return sign = 1, magnitude = -(positive.magnitude ^ -negative.magnitude)

member.name: T:Deveel.Math.MathContext
member.summary: Immutable objects describing settings such as rounding mode and digit precision for the numerical operations provided by class .

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.MathContext.Decimal128
member.summary: A which corresponds to the IEEE 754r quadruple decimal precision format: 34 digit precision and rounding.

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.MathContext.Decimal32
member.summary: A which corresponds to the IEEE 754r single decimal precision format: 7 digit precision and rounding.

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.MathContext.Decimal64
member.summary: A which corresponds to the IEEE 754r double decimal precision format: 16 digit precision and rounding.

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.MathContext.Unlimited
member.summary: A for unlimited precision with rounding.

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.MathContext.precision
member.summary: The number of digits to be used for an operation; results are rounded to this precision.

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.MathContext.roundingMode
member.summary: A object which specifies the algorithm to be used for rounding.

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.MathContext.chPrecision
member.summary: An array of containing: 'p','r','e','c','i','s','i','o','n','='. It's used to improve the methods related to conversion.

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.MathContext.chRoundingMode
member.summary: An array of containing: 'r','o','u','n','d','i','n','g','M','o','d','e','='. It's used to improve the methods related to conversion.

member.name: M:Deveel.Math.MathContext.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructs a new with the specified precision and with the rounding mode .
member.param: The precision for the new context.
member.remarks: If the precision passed is zero, then this implies that the computations have to be performed exact, the rounding mode in this case is irrelevant.
member.exception: If is smaller than zero.

member.name: M:Deveel.Math.MathContext.#ctor(System.Int32,Deveel.Math.RoundingMode)
member.summary: Constructs a new with the specified precision and with the specified rounding mode.
member.param: The precision for the new context.
The rounding mode for the new context.
member.remarks: If the precision passed is zero, then this implies that the computations have to be performed exact, the rounding mode in this case is irrelevant.
member.exception: If is smaller than zero.

member.name: P:Deveel.Math.MathContext.Precision
member.summary: Get the precision of the context.
member.remarks: The precision is the number of digits used for an operation. Results are rounded to this precision. The precision is guaranteed to be non negative. If the precision is zero, then the computations have to be performed exact, results are not rounded in this case.

member.name: P:Deveel.Math.MathContext.RoundingMode
member.summary: Gets the rounding mode of the context, that is the strategy used to round results.

member.name: M:Deveel.Math.MathContext.ToString
member.summary: Returns the string representation for this instance.
member.remarks: The string has the form "precision=<precision> roundingMode=<roundingMode>" where <precision> is an integer describing the number of digits used for operations and <roundingMode> is the string representation of the rounding mode.
member.returns: Returns the string that describes the current context.

members.member: Static library that provides all multiplication of {@link BigInteger} methods.
Break point in digits (number of {@code int} elements) between Karatsuba and Pencil and Paper multiply.
An array with powers of ten that fit in the type {@code int}. ({@code 10^0,10^1,...,10^9})
An array with powers of five that fit in the type {@code int}. ({@code 5^0,5^1,...,5^13})
An array with the first powers of ten in {@code BigInteger} version. ({@code 10^0,10^1,...,10^31})
An array with the first powers of five in {@code BigInteger} version. ({@code 5^0,5^1,...,5^31})
Performs a multiplication of two BigInteger and hides the algorithm used. @see BigInteger#multiply(BigInteger)
Provides primality probabilistic methods.
All prime numbers with bit length lesser than 10 bits.
All {@code BigInteger} prime numbers with bit length lesser than 8 bits.

It encodes how many i-bit primes there are in the table for {@code i=2,...,10}. For example {@code offsetPrimes[6]} says that from index {@code 11} exists {@code 7} consecutive {@code 6}-bit prime numbers in the array.

member.name: T:Deveel.Math.RoundingMode
member.summary: Enumerates the possible strategies used to round results.

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.RoundingMode.Up
member.summary: Positive values are rounded towards positive infinity and negative values towards negative infinity. (x.Round().Abs() >= x.Abs()

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.RoundingMode.Down
member.summary: The values are rounded towards zero. (x.Round().Abs() <= x.abs())

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.RoundingMode.Ceiling
member.summary: Rounds towards positive infinity: for positive values this rounding mode behaves as , for negative values as (x.round() >= x)

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.RoundingMode.Floor
member.summary: Rounds towards negative infinity: for positive values this rounding mode behaves as , for negative values as (x.Round() <= x).

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.RoundingMode.HalfUp
member.summary: Values are rounded towards the nearest neighbor and ties are broken by rounding up.

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.RoundingMode.HalfDown
member.summary: Values are rounded towards the nearest neighbor and ties are broken by rounding down.

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.RoundingMode.HalfEven
member.summary: Values are rounded towards the nearest neighbor and ties are broken by rounding to the even neighbor.

member.name: F:Deveel.Math.RoundingMode.Unnecessary
member.summary: The rounding operations throws an for the case that rounding is necessary (i.e. for the case that the value cannot be represented exactly)

member.name: M:Deveel.Math.Utils.URShift(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Operates a shift on the given integer by the number of bits specified.
member.param: The number to shift.
The number of bits to shift the given number.
member.returns: Returns an int representing the shifted number.

member.name: P:Deveel.Math.Messages.Culture
member.summary: Overrides the current thread's CurrentUICulture property for all resource lookups using this strongly typed resource class.
